tourName: Namibia wildlife tour, desert and marine life
generalInfo:
When people think of Namibia most people do not think of dolphins and flamingos; but instead the massive sand dunes of Sossusvlei and the herds of elephants in Etosha. But Namibia is a wonderful location were both the desert and the ocean can be explored for wildlife.

Introduction:
We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching all over the world and we have a great range of wildlife safaris of Southern Africa including many itineraries to Namibia. Namibia is a vast country with some of the most photogenic and stunning scenery anywhere in the world. Home to one of the world’s largest national parks (Etosha National Park) and the world’s oldest desert (Namib Desert) the seemingly barren Namibian wilderness is alive with wildlife.

This tour is an exploration around some of the most iconic and beautiful places in this wonderful country. But as well as exploring the will known locations we will also explore Walvis Bay searching for wildlife.

Unlike many other safari destinations in Africa it is not just the wildlife that is mesmerising here, instead the landscape plays a major role in brining the wildlife and the wilderness to life. Whether it is the colossal orange sand dunes of Sossusvlei or the eerie petrified trees of Deadvlei, the very moon like eroded hills and canyons north of Swakopmund or indeed the vast rugged terrain of Damarland and the white empty expanse of the Etosha Pan, there is incredible and unique landscapes all over Namibia.

Being mostly a desert environment Namibia it is easy to think of the country as being devoid of life, certainly it is hard to believe that the country could boast the largest population of rhinos in the world (outside of protected parks), or large numbers of elephants, lions, leopards, cheetahs and other iconic African wildlife. But that is Namibia, a land of contradictions a land of extreme environments which has led to the evolution of wildlife that has come up with some incredible adaptations to survive. Including handstanding beetles, cartwheeling spiders, dancing lizards, sand-swimming lizards and sidewinding snakes among others. On this trip you will be taken to see some of the smallest but most bizarre inhabitants of the desert as well as enjoying many game drives in the presence of elephants, giraffes, lions, rhinos and other large African wildlife. With endemic Heaviside's dolphins, Cape fur seals, turtles and a huge number of marine birds, Walvis Bay is a great location to visit and see many species which most people who visit Namibia do not usually see.

Namibia is truly a unique destination and with the help of our expert naturalist guides, skippers, drivers all have intimate knowledge of the wildlife and habitats you will be visiting, we know you will be great hands when it comes to getting the most out of this Namibian safari.

There are so many different places to visit in Namibia, this is itinerary hits all of the key destinations, however if you wish to visit other places we are experts are tailoring wildlife and cultural tours to Namibia to suit any requirement. All you have to do is to get in touch with your budget and your group size and where you would like to go and we will come back to you with an itinerary and quote for your perfect Namibian wildlife safari tour.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner) where mentioned, in some locations lunch and dinner are not included (please refer to the itinerary), such as in Windhoek and Swakopmund. We have our own private air conditioned 4x4 vehicles as well as wildlife watching boats with an excellent driver / captain for all transfers, game drives and boat cruises. Where possible we use two brilliant guides; first a professional zoologist (when available - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) who will escort you on all your excursions and we also have very knowledgeable English speaking local naturalist guides who have decades of experience working and guiding through Namibia (and elsewhere in Southern Africa). Your naturalist escort is an expert in wildlife biology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. The local guides have spent years searching out the best wildlife watching locations and have an unrivalled knowledge where we are going to visit. Where needed we further employ local guides at specific locations where their intimate knowledge of individual reserves and parks is invaluable in finding our targeted species. We also include all vehicle safaris, guided walks, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. We include more time spent in the field searching for wildlife per day than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the Namibian wilderness, night safaris are available in Etosha, however they are only available with the park services and it is a first come first basis and so you will have to speak to your guide on arrival there and book places on these (this is not included). A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on the wildlife that you are likely to see which are available to watch throughout the tour (subject to availability of a zoologist guide - zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us).

Seasons:

There are reasons to visit Namibia at any time of year, however we prefer to visit in September – November where the temperatures are a little cooler and the wildlife plentiful.
Namibia has more than 300 days of sunshine per year. It is situated at the southern edge of the tropics; the Tropic of Capricorn cuts the country about in half. The winter (June–August) is generally dry, both rainy seasons occur in summer, the small rainy season between September and November, the big one between February and April. Humidity is low, and average rainfall varies from almost zero in the coastal desert to more than 600mm in the Caprivi Strip.
Weather and climate in the coastal area are dominated by the cold, north-flowing Benguela Current of the Atlantic Ocean which accounts for very low precipitation (<50mm per year), frequent dense fog, and overall lower temperatures than in the rest of the country. Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our wildlife watching holidays are guided by an experienced naturalist guides as well as local drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife you’re watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• We can also offer further wildlife watching activities if they present themselves whilst on the trip. For example our local guides keep their ears to the ground and have many contacts and if and when a new location of animal is known and reliably seen we can head there to experience it. We do our best to include as many wildlife activities as possible in all of our itineraries.
• Depending on budget and interest we have a range of different accommodation packages to offer, from luxury top end lodges, national park safari lodges and camps which often offer unbelievable wildlife watching deep inside national parks as well as camping. A mobile camping safari of Namibia is very popular and all of your camping gear will be provided.
• Spend all the daylight hours searching for wildlife and visiting various natural wonders and stunning landscapes.
• All the above reasons give this, our Namibian wildlife safaris a great success rate of seeing the best wildlife around here. We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout Southern Africa so that we can try and find and observe some of the rarer and more elusive species. We have great itineraries and expertise in all Southern African countries (Namibia, South Africa, Botswana, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Malawi and Mozambique) and can arrange trips to find some of the rarer species such as aardvarks, aardwolves, brown hyenas and black-footed cats among other species. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour visit various locations within Namibia. We will start and end the trip in the capital Windhoek and in between visit Etosha National Park, Namib Desert, Walvis Bay, Damaraland and Skeleton Coast..

Fitness Level:

The vast majority of wildlife watching is all done from a vehicle and whilst there is some walking, most of the walking is over flat sand or rock. However you are welcome to walk up the iconic sand dunes in Sossusvlei if you wish. However even this is not too difficult and requires no special fitness level. The longest hike is to Deadvlei and this is around 2 hours there and back and the walk is mostly flat. The biggest consideration is the heat, it is very hot in the deserts of Namibia during the day.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 12 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Otjiwarongo - Once you arrive at Windhoek International airport your drive / guide will meet you and then you will be transferred northwards to Frans Indongo Lodge. You will then enjoy the rest of the afternoon at leisure.

Damaraland - On day 4 you will leave the lodge after breakfast and one last morning game drive and then head towards and into Damaraland. Here you will have the chance to see the woman of the local Himba tribe with their ochre-stained bodies and intricate head decorations; you will continue onwards to Palmwag where the specially adapted desert elephants. You will check into your accommodation, at the Desert Rhino Camp. This is a unique place which is home to the largest free ranging population of black rhino in the world. You will be treated to game drives, possibly guided walks and other activities here to track down the elusive rhino, desert elephants, gemsbok, Hartmanns zebra, springbok as well as predators like leopards, cheetah, lions and brown and spotted hyenas. Day 5 will be a full day spent exploring the Desert Rhino Camp and hopefully finding many of these magnificent and very rare mammals.

Skeleton Coast National Park - After breakfast you will be transferred to the coast and through the southern section of the Skeleton Coast National Park, the Skeleton Coast is so named because of its treacherous waters which have brought about the destruction of many a vessel in the rough seas. You will continue along the coast to Cape Cross Lodge. This lodge is located in Cape Cross where the largest colony of Cape fur seals in the world is located.

Namib Desert - After breakfast this morning you will take a short drive south via the multic-oloured lichen covered fields towards the quaint German colonial town of Swakopmund located on the edge of the Namib Desert. The surrounding areas make for spectacular pictures and the small town has many delightful shops and curio stalls where you can collect those typically African souvenirs. After checking in you will then have the rest of the day at leisure.

Walvis Bay - Today will be a day on the water of Walvis Bay. You will head to the harbour after breakfast where you will join the adventure of a seal and dolphin cruise. During the trip light snacks, local oysters and sparking wine will be served as we enjoy the playful Cape fur seals and the equally playful common bottle-nose dolphins and the very rare and endemic Heavyside dolphins around the boat. It is not just marine mammals here as the bird life is also a thrill with white-chinned petrels, Wilson’s storm petrels, Cape gannets, black oystercatchers and even African penguins regularly seen. There is also a good chance of finding the huge and very rare leatherback turtle as they feed on the jellyfish which are abundant here, ocean sunfish and large shoals of ducky dolphins are also sometimes seen. In addition to this whale (humpbacks and southern right whales) are becoming more common but only between August and October. The afternoon will be spent at your leisure as you can explore the town of Walvis Bay.

Naankuse Wildlife Sanctuary - Today after breakfast you will set out on the road back to Windhoek but we will stop at our accommodation, level – luxury safari lodge (Naankuse Lodge) in between the airport and Windhoek. Here you will have the opportunity to get close to some of the top predators in the world. As the sanctuary specialises with cheetah and leopards.
Home - This morning you will be taken to the airport in Windhoek, in time to catch your return flight home.
